body.head: Khuc Thua Du builds the sovereignty.

p.s: In the late ninth century, China was engulfed in chaos.
The Tang was unable to exercise its control over our country as before and changed the post of protector to that of governor.
The governor, on behalf of the Tang authority, had the power to determine all matters including the selection of his heir.
Khuc Thua Du was a local chief whose homeland was in Cuc Bo, Hong Chau (Ninh Giang, Hai Duong).
The Khuc was a big, age-old and well-known family.
Khuc Thua Du was a man of generosity and philanthropy who was greatly admired by the people in the locality.

In mid 905, taking advantage of the internal dispute in the Tang court and the disposal of their governor in our country, Khuc Thua Du launched a revolt, captured Tong Binh citadel and proclaimed himself governor.
The Tang dynasty was put before a fait accompli.
Early next year, the Tang emperor officially promoted Khuc Thua Du as governor.
From then, Khuc Thua Du nominally got a post of mandarin of the Tang dynasty but, in fact, the domination of the Chinese feudal regime in our country was terminated.
Thus our country gained back its sovereignty.
This served as an initial important step so as to regain complete national independence at a later stage.
Khuc Thua Du was in the position of governor for two years before he passed away.
His son Khuc Hao succeeded his career proclaiming himself governor.
He immediately set to build the country along the line that "political affairs mean, in essence, charity, simplicity and happiness to people".
Khuc Hao revised the administrative sector and assigned his men to look after the affairs to the commune level.
The new authority also revised the land tax system and promulgated a more appropriate one and, at the same time, lifted all hard and duties.
Khuc Hao also restored the household registration to serve as a basis for tax collection and recruitment for the army.
